I think you messed up on 'phase' You can have to frequencies that are "out of phase" and they end up fighting each other - or if they are 'in phase' They would be complementing each other. To achieve resonance, you need to get the same frequency and you need complementary phasing.
BTW, stereo amplifiers see this all the time. They get feedback from the speakers and the amplifier must have enough power to overcome the natural resonance of the system. One way this is measured is the damping factor of the amplifier. Dampen out the resonance..... (its actually more than just resonance, because a moving speaker can generate power at all frequencies - but the natural resonance of the speaker is typically the toughest part.)

Resonant frequency is slightly lower than natural frequency. wr = wn*(1-2z^2)^1/2 where z is the damping ratio. In most cases they are effectively the same because z is minuscule, but if the system is highly damped it will be significantly different. Natural frequency of a damped system is similar: wd = wn*(1-z^2)^1/2. wn is just borrowed from undamped systems to make math easier.

I wish you would have just talked with music theorist. What is happening is simple to explain. There is a set of frequencies associated with the harmonic series. As you approach the correct frequency from below, the waves will suddenly snap up to the next frequency. This is probably how brass instruments work!
It is extremely difficult to bend a pitch up or down even a few cents (or hertz) without jumping to the next note in the instrument's overtone series. For instance, a trombone in first position jumps up from the fundamental B-flat to F, which is a perfect fifth interval (a 50% increase in frequency for you physicists). However, when the tube is shorter (i.e. just singing through your hand or buzzing through a mouthpiece), the resistance to hitting certain frequencies is minimal, so it's much easier to slide through the full range.

I'd suggest that a follow-up vid to this one might be an introduction to psychoacoustics, which, according to Wikipedia may be simplistically defined as "...the branch of psychophysics involving the scientific study of sound perception and audiology—how humans perceive various sounds."
Again, simply stated, there are perceptual equivalents to the physical characteristics of sound waves: frequency, pitch; amplitude, loudness, harmonic complexity, timbre, etc. This is also the area of study that provides an actual correct answer to the question "if a tree falls in a forest and there is no one there to hear it fall, is there a sound?"
Also it is in this field of study that the design of theatres and concert halls is carefully examined and planned, as is the Doppler effect and other sound experiences that are not purely physical, such as understanding the physics that helps one distinguish the music style of Beethoven from that of Mozart!

As a high end audio equipment guy, we deal with this all of the time.  The terms used in our industry are standing waves (force feedback) and phasing.   When placing an object such as a loudspeaker into a room and sending it an amplified signal it produces soundwaves that expand outwards from the speaker, these sound waves bounce of of other surfaces in the room and particularly with bass notes this can create standing waves where the multiple soundwaves in the room and stack up and increase the force (volume) at a specific frequency or they can phase and nearly cancel each other out.   You can experience this yourself by turning on a radio or stereo in a mostly enclosed space setting it to play either test tones or a piece of music that doesn't change much and then walk around the room, particularly near the walls and corners you will notice certain frequencies increasing or decreasing in volume.   With a stereo system if you take the two speakers into the middle of the room and point them toward each other at different distances you can do the same thing, or by rewiring one of the speakers (reversing the polarity of the wires) you can make the speakers out of phase with each and the sound will become very muffled as the speakers are creating nearly opposite soundwaves canceling out most of the sound energy;  Just remember to switch the wires with the power to the system off and switch them back to normal after you are done with the experiment.

Very interesting!  You have touched on a subject, that has some controversy surrounding it, in the Audiophile field.   Why do speakers with fairly small magnets driven with a vacuum tube amplifier, produce more bass, than a transistor power amp driving speakers with large magnets and stronger magnetic fields.  At the resonant frequency of the speaker, the speaker cone and voice coil are out of phase by about 90 degrees of the voltage driving them.  Tube amplifiers attempt to supply a current proportional to the input signal voltage, (to the amp),... because the current is maximum when the voltage crosses the zero voltage crossing, and the older style tube amps with coupling transformer, and lower negative feedback, have a lower damping factor, the bass at the resonant frequency comes through fine, even though the speaker exhibits it's highest resistance at the resonant frequency.  In a  transistor amp where the output voltage tends to follow precisely the input voltage, the 90 degrees out of phase signal at bass resonance to the speaker, provides negative feedback to the speaker, just as the cone is going towards it's maximum excursion,  and damps the speaker which ceases to be driven, and is beginning to generate a back electromotive force.  In addition, as the Voltage signal from the amp goes to zero, the current also drops to zero so the speakers motion in response also tries to go to zero.  Looking at the phase relationship when the output signal is highest, the mass of the speaker cone and voicecoil, has enough inertia as a whole, at low frequencies such that they are just starting to move, even though the voltage applied to them is at it's peak.  So even though two amps  (one tube, and the other transistor) may seem to have identical frequency response, and power driving a resistor, the tube amp, when checked with a microphone, will deliver more bass into a fairly resonant speaker, (high "Q") with identical voltage output (measured with the resistor load).  Transistor amps tend to always deliver the same voltage output as the input, while tube amps also show a loading effect, meaning the output voltage drops under load, and the voltage and current output will increase, (also out of phase) into a highly reactive load,.. this is also partly the result of how hysteresis in an output transformer can release energy, when the signal applied to it crosses through zero after having been driven to the point of "charging" the transformers iron core.  All in all The transistor amp behaves more like singing directly into the PVC pipe (pressure loading), versus singing across it, like it is a flute, which is more the way a vacuum tube amplifier would behave.

Bugles have this to where it can only play certain notes (listen to the songs Taps or Reveille).  Some bugle corps will use bugles tuned to different notes so that they can cover every note.  Drum and bugle corps will have only two valves, instead of three that a trumpet has, to still allow themselves to be called a bugle, since a bugle by definition can't cover every note on the scale.  With a bugle, a player can pull the note up (sharp) or down (flat) a bit but it's really hard pull all the way up to hit some notes.  Alpine horns will have three players, where each alpine horn will be at a different length to cover every note since they are basically just unrolled bugles. Then the three alpine players will play a 3 note chord, or they may play a little melody by alternating who plays which note (like bell players do).  So this is not some new hole in music, it has been around as long as ram's horn bugles have been around - many moons.

A halfwave open stub is equal to a quarterwave shorted stub. Put plainly, a tube exactly half the size would act exactly the same, at the same frequency, if it was capped on the end. Then when you seal your mouth around the other end, both ends are obstructed. Although the tube is open on the end, when you reach a specific resonance, the tube effectively becomes plugged on the end. This should continue at resonant frequencies equal to any multiple of a halfwave.

To test the theory loosely tape a piece of paper to the end so it forms a flap. Sing into the tube and observe if the flap begins to close at resonance.

Us trumpeters experience the inability to play all frequencies all the time. The length and construction of the pipe we buzz our lips into causes us to only be able to play some "slots" of a frequency range. Back in college, in my voice class, we learned about and studied this kind of stuff. In vocal lingo, the point where two types of voice meet is called your break. The scoop sound in the tube is kind of what it sounds like when you're practicing. You will hear voices having trouble singing a note or two near their personal break. Often times, we learn to control the break with added tension on our voice. This is what ultimately gave vocal cord issues with singers like Jordan Sparks or Adele, and also explains the mess up Idina Menzel had on New Years Eve (Not to single out ladies, it's just what I remember off the top of my head).

My voice teacher (Dr. Mary Logan Hastings) had me go through a tension detox, and literally, when you truly relax your vocal cords, your pitch goes out of control, but if you bring the tension back and try to control it, it's like putting your feet down when learning to ride a bike. You need to just keep the breath moving, and let whatever comes out come out, and eventually you will learn how to ride along with it.

I spent that semester locking myself in the soundproof practice rooms singing scales and sounding like a tone-deaf yodeler, and after a few weeks of that, suddenly I had a real good handle on my voice. It was amazing. I have since gone on to teach instrumental music, and when I sing, it's loaded with the same tension I had before I took the voice class.

As she sings into the tube and raises her pitch, there will eventually be a point in the resonance that cancels out vibrations of the sound waves, forcing the voice to sing at a higher pitch.  These points are the border intervals of "partials" of the harmonic series.  Brass instrument players demonstrate this whenever they play arpeggio intervals involving partials of the fundamental tone.  They can manipulate a pitch up or down from the center of its natural tone to a certain limit that then crosses over to the next higher or lower partial of that particular length of brass tubing.  Playing intervals along a group of partials is how a trumpeter can play the bugle call, "Reveille".

Do please take note of the fact that brass instruments have had many design incarnations. This is an ongoing attempt to make it easier to properly place all of the notes, across the entire range of the instrument (which can be a very large range), such that they respond easily and in tune (as close as possible, please). The French Horn and the Trombone have advantages in the tuning area (especially the French horn - hand in the bell and all...), but the Tuba has more "give", or lip adjustment, to notes than the Trumpet. The Trunpet takes a bit more work to master intonation - and the better the design (for all wind instruments)... the better the results.

There are certainly notes that are actually NOT really "playable" on Trumpet - the C an octave (look it up) below the treble clef is a fine example of this. The shape of the instrument is not conducive to resonance at that frequency. Also, there are certain notes on brass/wind instruments that are tricky. Those notes (frequencies, if you prefer) are difficult because of where they lie in relation to the harmonic overtone series - some overtones are VERY flat (below the desired frequency). Some overtones are not responsive and some are sharp (above the desired frequency).

This physical world is NOT perfect - at least in terms of wind instruments!

You get a similar effect with resonator tubes on Marimbas and Vibraphones, that kind of thing. It is a common misconception that the resonance in the tube is what directly makes the vibrating bar louder by adding acoustic energy. Actually, it does the opposite. Vibrating bars are a dipole sound source and they are small compared with the wavelength in air, so the front and back waves, being opposite phase to each other, cancel out fairly well - the bar's fundamental doesn't ring out loudly in free space. The resonator tube "eats" the sound waves from the underside of the bar, at the resonant frequency, thus reducing the cancellation with the sound wave from the top of the bar, allowing it to radiate loudly into the air. The resonator makes the bar louder by removing acoustic energy! In light of this, perhaps, it is not surprising that it becomes difficult to sing the resonant frequency directly into a tube that is right by your mouth.

This principle is used in speaker enclosures, in order to design bass reflex.
When the frequency is above the frequency of the baffle (usually a tube of some length and diameter), the pressure is to high, so, the air cannot escape from this baffle and the response of the enclosure matches this of a "closed box enclosure". AT resonant frequency of the baffle, the sound gets amplified due to the resonance of the tube. It's like having a 2nd speaker that plays synchronously (stationary waves) the same frequency (Although, there is a slight delay of n cycles, so that's why the is a slight "reverb" effect at these frequencies). On a speaker that the the frequency of the incoming signal is usually a mix of frequencies, this results on a physical/mechanical "Bass Boost" (since, the specific frequency is amplified, and the rest work as mentioned above).
On frequencies lower then the resonance point, the baffle works like an open hole, so the sound gets attenuated even more than when it gets played on a closed enclosure.
So, the whole idea of a bass reflex is to be "tuned" right where the physical frequency response of the loudspeaker itself starts to "be less efficient". That results in a slightly better low-end response of the speaker-system than before.

In the automotive world if the exhaust pipe size or the length is wrong then you'll have a loss of power at a particular RPM. The resonance of the exhaust note can reflect back to the exhaust port, cause the next exhaust pulse to stumble, slow down and cause performance to drop.

There's another way to visualize this:  A tube is a resonant system if one end is closed and the other is open.  More technically, you need a high impedance at one end and a low impedance at the other end. The frequency of resonance will be such that its wavelength is four times the length of the pipe; but that's not important to this mental exercise.  Well, technically you can have resonance in a tube with two closed ends;  it would act like a dipole.  But anyways, so the vocal cords are like a closed end and the mouth is the open end.  But if we try to sing into a resonant pipe, we are creating a high impedance (closed) end as we place the pipe against our lips, leaving the far end as the low impedance end (open).  But in so doing we are turning our mouth into a high impedance end, whereas it would be the low impedance end, when we are singing. To make things worse, the load is not purely resistive, as it would be if you are trying to sing into a tightly compressed fiberglass-filled pillow, but rather a reactive load that acts like a weight above some frequency, and as a spring below it, which is what a resonant system does.

Anyone who has ever played a saxophone in either a jazz or especially blues style, or has played a harmonica (a good harmonica player that can bend notes) understands completely how changing the volume of your mouth and nasal passages at the back of your throat alters the frequency of the instrument and the note it "wants" to play "naturally". A REALLY good saxophone player can force the horn to play in it's upper octave (double resonant frequency) without opening the octave key by "tuning the vocal track" or shaping the back of their throat. Think of the raspy sound of the sax in "Yakety Sax" (Benny Hill used this tune all the time) That, at least the original recording, is a saxophone playing the upper octave without the use of the octave key. Although a trombone can bend notes mechanically and brass instruments can be forced into double resonance, this "resonant tuning" is more easily achieved with reed instruments where the vibrations of the reed also resonates into the player's vocal track. Benny Goodman was known for his ability to bend the notes of his clarinet at least two full steps, if not more. The problem is, once you stumble on to this control over the instrument, one can overuse it. Bending notes on a saxophone can be dynamic or it can make it sound like you broke something if you do too much of it.

In a tube to which you sing a note there is resonance at several frequencies that are harmonics of the fundamental. This is due to the standing wave of sound forming at those frequencies.
This has to do with nodes and antinodes forming inside the tube. You have resonant frequencies when the length of the tube is a multiple of the distance between nodes (or antinodes).
But the tube doesn't want to "play" notes that correspond to a node in one extremity and an antinode on the other.
The tube resonating frequencies are the easiest to sing through it because they the natural ones. This is what makes flutes and trumpets work. But the fundamental can be to low for your vocal range. But you will be able to tune on harmonics. The notes you can not sing through the tube are in the intervals of the harmonics.

I think you've discovered the difference between "chest voice" and "head voice". Usually amateur singers have a break between the two. Trained singers can make that break either nonexistent or very small.
Here's the theory: an amateur singer is NOT tuning their vocal tract resonant frequency to the note they are singing. When they sing lower notes (chest voice), their vocal folds are vibrating slower than the resonant frequency of their vocal tract. When they sing higher (head voice), their vocal folds are vibrating faster than the resonant frequency of their vocal tract. They break when their vocal folds are at the same frequency as the vocal tract.
There are two strategies a trained singer could use to avoid this break.
First, they might change the resonant frequency of their vocal tract dynamically, so that as they switch notes from chest to head voice, they quickly drop the resonant frequency of their vocal tract to avoid getting the two at the same frequency.
A different and perhaps superior strategy would require changing both ends of the vocal tract, which will require not just using your mouth to alter the top end but also using your chest muscles to alter the bottom end. A resonant standing wave in the vocal tract will have nodes -- places where the pressure or velocity amplitude is zero. If one of those velocity nodes is where the vocal folds are, there is no way to couple energy from the vocal fold into sound. That's why you can't sing the note. But if you get the zero-pressure maximum-velocity node on top of the vocal fold, you get maximum energy coupling. I suspect that well trained singers have learned to dynamically alter their vocal tract to line up a max-velocity node on their vocal folds at all notes, eliminating the problem of the break between chest and voice entirely.

A pipe of any given length has a fundamental pitch related to that length, and that can be shifted upwards or downwards depending on the material, and the bore (diameter).
When you put a pipe up to your face, it is (usually) pretty long, and so its fundamental frequency/pitch is right in the average person's singing voice.
The harmonic series defines which other frequencies it vibrates at best and more easily, because it is not just the resonating frequency; there are infinite frequencies going up forever (and possibly down, but that's a different topic). When you ascend in pitch, there comes a point to where you hop to the next partial, because the tubing prefers to vibrate at some frequencies after others. This is how brass instruments work. It's very easy to be around the frequencies in the harmonic series, but anything outside of it is very difficult to be able to play. There's too much to explain with the harmonic series to explain in a comment, though, so just know it is a multiple of the base frequency.

When a soprano singer changes the shape of their mouth/throat, it causes the overall shape and size to change, resulting in a change in pitch. This would be how they use it to change.

Next time you sing through a tube, just pay attention as you ascend. Every time you go up a partial, or one of those breaking points, each one should get closer and closer in pitch, to where the gap in leaps gets smaller and smaller.

This also explains singing through your hand; the "pipe/tube" of your hand is so short, the fundamental pitch/frequency is so high, it is well above your average voice. (Considering the tube could be about 8 times longer than your hand, and each half size jumps an octave, its primary resonating pitch would be 3 octaves above the pipe. Ouch)

Really, it just comes down to how strange our world can be. Everything has a set pitch it vibrates best at, and an infinite series of multiples that go above them.

This is well known phenomena in transmission line theory. A transmission line will transform its load impedance into different input impedance, depending on relationship between its length and the wavelength.


For example, a half-wavelength (and multiple of it) line is an impedance repeater. Its input impedance will be equal its load impedance.


A quarter-wavelength (plus multiple of half-wavelengths) line is an impedance invertor. Its input impedance is equal to the transmission line's own impedance squared, divided by the load impedance.
For example, if you have zero load impedance, the input impedance will be infinite, and vice versa.


An open tube is effectively loaded onto 3D open air impedance, which I suppose is a half of 1D air column impedance (need to find out exactly). If you hit impedance inversion frequency, this will become four times open air impedance.


When you hit the frequency which experiences much bigger impedance, this makes it like you sing with your mouth closed.

WHY?! You ask?
Here is what I believe is happening, having only taken High School physics, and learning online some pop-science pseudo-physics.
The frequency of the sound they are making is causing pressure to build up inside the tube. Lower sounds, like in a didgeridoo, can flow more freely out of the tube because they aren't bouncing around so fast, which is why it's easier to make a lower pitch. When you get to the higher pitches, the frequency increases, and pressure builds up to a point where a higher amount of the waves are actually bouncing back into your mouth and into your larynx. When you finally reach the pitch, you've reached a "breakeven" point wherein the air molecules are bouncing at a frequency that is the inverse of the pitch you're trying to produce in larynx, so it comes out muffled.


Since the tube is rather uniformly smooth, the waves are more consistently bouncing back and forth. This is why it doesn't work with your hand, as it's both too short, so you'd have to produce a VERY high pitch, and it's not as smooth a surface, so even if you were able to produce a high enough pitch not enough of the waves would be bouncing back into your larynx.


A better way to illustrate this would be to imagine you have air molecules in larynx that vibrate in a consistent manner in order to produce the pitch. When the pitch gets high enough, those same air molecules are vibrating in such a way that actually "cancels" out the pitch you are making. Active noise-cancelling headphones do the same thing. They produce an inverse sound wave in order to cancel out the incoming sound waves.


It's either that, or the wavelength of the pitch nearly perfectly matches the size of the tube, causing it to "miss" the tube entirely when it comes out. Since you're used to the pressure beforehand, the instant release of pressure causes you to make that sound because you're pushing more than you needed to at that moment.

When you talk about professional singers "tuning their vocal tract", it sounds like you are referring to what most singers know as singing across "the break". Because the length of the vocal tract (from the vocal chords to the lips of the mouth) is roughly the same in most people, most will experience "the break" when they try to sing through the range of frequencies between about D5 and E5. It takes some practice to learn how to modify your vocal tract so you can sing through "the break" without your voice cracking. This is a different phenomenon than switching from "chest voice" to "head voice" (or "falsetto"). In men, "the break" also happens to occur right around the pitch their voice also wants to switch to/from falsetto. But in women, "the break" is in their lower range, still usually around D5 to E5 in pitch.

At the resonant frequency (and very near it), the air in the tube produces a standing wave. The human voice requires air moving out (or in, but not both) through the vocal folds to function properly. Because there is a standing wave, that is not possible. Put another way, when you sing, you're pushing air out of your lungs. The pipe creates a standing wave at the frequency you are trying to produce, which stops the air coming out of your lungs. Thus, either the pitch has to change, or your voice stops working. Since you keep trying to push air out of your lungs, the pitch is the thing to give out.

This is why port length and shape in subwoofer assemblies is so important. when you have an open ended port like this with a dead stop (cut straight end.) and you place a frequency wave through the tube, you hit a frequency length that matches the length of the tube... what ends up happening is a low pressure wave comes out past the end of the tube... it causes the atmosphere to rush in from the sides of the tube behind it to fill the low pressure area... in turn causing a back pressure wave to travel back up the tube and hit your vocal chords (or other radiating structure), effectively canceling out the next wave coming out.


interestingly enough, attaching a horn to the end of your tube... you'd find that it would nearly eliminate most of these cancellations as this makes the "length" of the "tube" vary from the center to the outside of the horn cone... since a sound wave must travel farther along the outside of the one vs the middle. the bigger the horn, the less cancellations there would be.

As a stereo guy, this is exactly what is going on in the port of a subwoofer. The port is tuned to a bottom frequency, the lowest the sub can play. The resonance causes a huge increase in resistance, which prevents the sub from moving so far it blows itself apart. At a certain point, it just "whooshes" and you get next to no sound. You can plot frequency vs. impedance of the circuit and see the spike where the resonant frequency lies.

Some have asked about the effect on a speaker if it were placed on a pipe. This is actually well known as it is part of designing a bass-reflex ported speaker cabinet. The answer is that the loading on the amplifier goes down. A speaker also has a "free air resonance" below which bass output plummets.  In tuning a cabinet, the port is tuned below this frequency. Thus the speaker works harder at it's free air resonance, and the cabinet extends the bass range of the speaker by making it more efficient below the point where the speaker output would normally start to drop off.

A pedantic note: You don't push with your vocal folds, you push with your abdominal muscles, which in turn push on the diaphragm, raising the pulmonary pressure and by extension the subglottic pressure until it overcomes the glottal resistance and the vocal folds come apart. The subglottic and supraglottic pressures then equalise rapidly, lowering the transglottic pressure and its abductive force, allowing the vocal folds to come together again and the process repeats. The vocal folds are not string oscillators but more like a valve that rapidly opens and closes.

That's why trumpets, horns... have valves, or trombones have a slide. These play a completely different role from the keys in woodwinds : for woodwinds, opening/shuting the holes give the possibility to lock the exact note, but for brass, opening/shuting valves or sliding the trombone do not makes the note, but simply changes the playable notes interval in the tube. For both, the note is made in the mouth, i.e. in the resonant cavity made of the chicks, the tongue and the mouthpiece. In the case of brass, the vibrating part are the lips, and in the case of woodwinds, the vibrating element is a wooden blade.


 In both cases the tube by itself adapts the acoustic impedence of the resonating system formed by the vibrating device and the cavity. Of course, this is true only if you don't try to play a note outside the "playable" interval (i.e. under or at resonance). That's the role of the valves on brass : as long as you want to play notes inside the playable interval for your tube, you don't need to change it's length. If you have to play outside, you've got to change the lenght : in a trombone you do it 'by hand', in a trumpet, you select a pre-determined tube lenght among a set of possible values...


Woodwinds offer both types of playing : fixed tube length, and sliding the notes "with the mouth", or just rely on the resonance of the tube length to lock the notes, using the keys... and the saxophone is a brass adapted to both types of playing !!

I love you Physics Girl. You found very interesting phenomena. The professor gave the clue why the sound just disappears at some frequency. However the explanation was not perfect. Another thing we should consider is that there are many resonance frequencies when we excite sound using a long pipe. Let’s say you are in the middle of two resonance frequencies f1 and f2, the vibration modes for the two frequencies excite simultaneously with opposite phase resulting in destructive interference. Your vocal cords drive the sound frequency, and all oscillation modes of the pipe can be excited in some extent according to the distance between the mode’s frequency and your voice frequency. And the excited oscillation with the specific mode has some definite amplitude and phase relation with your driving voice. Because your voice frequency is greater than f1 and smaller than f2, the f1 vibration mode will be at around opposite-phase and the f2 vibration mode will be at around in-phase with your driving sound. The two oscillation modes interfer destructively. This is why you cannot make the note in the middle of resonance frequencies of the pipe.

This is probably similar to the way a horn (such as a trumpet) works. You play a trumpet by buzzing your lips into the mouthpiece, and it vibrates the whole instrument. Now obviously you can buzz your lips at a whole range of frequencies normally. However, when you're playing a horn, you can only make a sound at one of the resonant frequencies. That's the main resonant frequency and the overtone series above it.  If you try really hard to hit notes in between, you can "bend" the resonant frequency very slightly, maybe by a half step or so, but you can't hit all the notes in between. That's why trumpets have valves. The valves change the length of the tube, thus changing the resonant frequencies so that you can hit all 12 notes in a standard western scale.

Funny how things will dovetail into others...many years back I read a fair amount about resonance with regards to automotive/motorcycle engine intake tracts. Neat thing there, since pretty much all consist of plastic parts these days, is that the resonance of the materials directing the airflow can be tuned to improve intake charging. We tend to think of the air going into a motor as a steady pull but it is actually in the form of discrete pulses as the intake valves open and close. That sets up pressure waves upstream in the tract, which, as you've shown, can either enhance or interfere with cylinder air charging. It's a subtle effect on a powerful motor, but if you're trying to wring every bit of performance out of it, you will consider it. When the intake resonance matches the cylinder charging requirements at peak power it can give it a noticeable bump. Oh and that weird ultra-low frequency drone you get when you have one back window down in most modern cars? Resonant frequency of the cabin, being expressed by the roof panel, as they aren't as stout as they used to be. The air trying to come in the window is creating overpressure in the cabin, the roof panel swells just a bit, then springs back, expelling air back out but creating a low pressure draw through the window, starting it over again...it's doing the same thing the jug is when you blow over the opening...at its natural frequency.

That would also explain why the consonants in opera signing seem softer and hard to hear relative to the held notes: after stopping a note it takes time for the resonance to build amplitude again on the next note.

You are probably aware of this, but in the event you aren't: Mixing/Audio engineers frequently check their mixes for phase issues. Because of the nature of low frequency waves much of these issues ocurr in the area of the spectrum occupied by the bass guitar and the kick drum. If soloed each instrument/track sounds good but when played together something is missing or "thin". This is usually because the wave frequency of both are canceling each other out to one extent or another. By flipping the phase 180° on one of the tracks one can often correct some or all of the phase cancelation. The same is true when, for example, double tracking guitars. I have encountered similar situations before when practicing saxophone. There’s a technique known as “growling” where you hum while playing to disrupt the reed’s resonance. However, when you sing in consonance (or within the harmonic spectrum) some neat things happen. If you match pitch, the reed will stop vibrating, like the tube. Almost like canceling each other out back to rest. If you sing a fifth above ( the third harmonic) the saxophone will play an octave lower (at the first harmonic). I hope this gives a different perspective to the problem, I’d love to see this taught in the perspective of harmonic consonance and dissonance.

They change the speed of how their lips vibrate which resonates through the instrument and changes the sound. And they can do this with only 3 buttons! The specific reason being out of phase with the natural frequency of the tube is a problem is very important. If you were to sing exactly at the resonant frequency, the note would probably still occur, it would just feel very very weird, throwing you off balance. As soon as you are singing at a pitch where the air in the tube is vibrating out of phase with the air in your throat, there will be moments when as the air you're singing is "moving out" of the tube, the air in the tube is "moving back" into your throat. This means that the oscillations in the tube are working against you.

You can get multiple resonant modes too. Like only a quarter of the wavelength could be inside the tube, or half. If you know the length of the tube you can use the resonant frequency to measure the speed of sound.

You can find the specific frequency by doing that same exercise, but instead of using your voice, you are buzzing your lips. When you find it, the frequency makes the tube vibrate incredibly aggressively. You can then match that pitch with your voice and it will vibrate the tube if you sing in proximity. If you sing with your lips pressed directly into the tube, you are essentially extending the length of the tube with your mouth and throat, and it will change the fundamental (or specific frequency). Musicians would call the engagement of higher frequencies that vibrate sympathetically with that fundamental a harmonic series. This is how just about all brass instruments work.

There are two sorts of resonance involved with air vibrating inside things; Organ pipe type resonance where the wavelength of the vibration bears a definite integer relationship with one dimension of the resonant cavity and Helmholtz resonance where the wavelength is typically very much larger than any typical dimension of the cavity.
A recorder or flute is organ pipe type resonance. But an ocarina uses Helmholtz resonance.
Whistling is Helmholtz resonance, singing is not. Really weird things happen if you design a resonant cavity where both types of resonance can occur at similar frequencies. Can you whistle and sing at the same time? I can just. But can you whistle and sing the same note?

Hey there, I just wanted to mention a common mistake: vocal folds are sometimes called vocal cords, not vocal chords. A vocal chord would be 3 or more notes sung by vocalists.

Also, all trained singers tune our vocal tracts in order to amplify a note we’re singing, not just sopranos.

Someone needs to point out that the frequency at which the voice breaking occurs is a result of the combination of the length of the tube and the vocal tract itself.

Also, sopranos are not the only ones who “tune” their vocal tract. All singers intuitively know that they have “registers”, or ranges of pitches they are able to sing with a certain vocal tract positions.

Singers also change the shape of their lips, tongue, and soft palate to shape the vowel sound, naturally emphasizing different frequencies in the harmonic series in the upper range of human hearing to change the vowel we hear.

Talk to a voice teacher or a choir teacher and they can tell you all about the practical application of this sort of information.

What would really blow your mind is some automotive intakes change shape to change resonant frequencies. This way the engine can be more flexible with a wide powerband. Long intakes make the power down low, short intakes high rpm power. The perfect resonant frequency catches the air on the back of a closed valve compressing it, it bounces back into the intake and springs into an open cylinder helping to fill it, like a super/turbo charger. It's why my 2.5l v6 can destroy a same era 5.0l v8. Mazda Klze v6, it has some engineering notes out there online that shows how it works. It was such an interesting feature I bought all 4 available intakes for the engine from the different cars it was in.

Musicians don't normally deal with this but audio engineers and producers do. Mixing desks have a phase flip on every channel because of phase cancellation when multiple microphones (like on a drum kit) are picking up the same source but the sound is reaching them at different times, causing certain frequencies to be cancelled out. Zooming way in on a music program would show most sound waves going in opposite directions which would half the volume and sound quality

It is the stretching of vocal cords that changes pitch not the throat wind pipe that only amplifies the note amplitue. Your throat muscles had full pitch control until you were linearly stretching them comfortably toward tube's resonance. At PVC tube's resonance frequency, however, you became a just a component of a larger externally resonating system which would then overpower your carefully increase of muscular stretch.


Imagine at 440 Hz, you were singing "A". While approaching the vicinity of A, e.g. 1 Hz below -- there would be a beat frequency of one cycle per second thumping your vocal cord stretching system confusing the perfect neural control (not aware of external thumping) cracking your voice. An inaccurate but more intuitive way to describe would be by imagining that for some reason one of the prongs of tuning fork attempting to oscillate at a frequency slightly different than its physically/inertially entangled pair. It would experience the beat frequency and would experience massive resistance for trying to defeat the mutually agreed "resonance inertia" -- breaking the contract. The tiny muscles stretching your vocal cords with delicate neural control feedback control loop (involving your ear) are not match to overpower the energy of a very stable meter long external oscillating column of PVC tube. Perhaps it has larger, more stubborn momentum, and could easily crush the feedback control loop involving the tiny muscles at beat frequency! Have fun!

My immediate thought was that sharp impedance curve near resonance frequency. This must be an impedance mismatch. Indeed, I find these curves: https://newt.phys.unsw.edu.au/jw/z.html. The PVC tube is essentially like a flute, which has an impedance minimum at resonance; your vocal duct is like a clarinet which has an impedance maximum. (The curve for voice box is also shown, characterized by maxima at resonant frequences.) When approaching the tube's resonance frequency, impedances of the two move to opposing extremes. What a surprising (and exciting) illustration of this common challenge in engineering!

Study the harmonic series of brass instruments (well, any tube which produces a pitch, really) and you will find the answer easily enough. Any tube of length "X" will be capable of producing a set series of notes which are a function of the length "X": the fundamental (the lowest note it can produce) and a series of increasingly higher notes called harmonics, all of which follow a specific mathematical pattern (Diameter is also a factor, but for our purposes here, it is negligible). The tube will easily transmit vibrations (produced by the player's lips) at frequencies which correlate to the harmonic series, while other frequencies will have a harder time passing through (though you can coax out certain notes if you don't mind sounding like a dying whale). But there comes a point where the source of vibration - the player's lips (or vocal cords as it applies to the video) cannot continue to vibrate without "jumping" up (or down) and skipping some notes. We call these different levels of vibration "partials" and they are vital to brass instruments like trumpets, trombones, French horns, tubas, and so on. It's all very similar to the way string players hit high harmonic tones by gently tapping the string at a special point called a node - only you can't sing into/through a string in the same way she sings into the pipes in the video. And before the trolls come out, yes, woodwinds use partials/harmonics, too - just not as extensively. I saw someone mention using a speaker to test this same phenomenon. About that - if you include the speaker as part of a sealed system inside the tube, you MIGHT get these results, but it would have to be a completely closed system in the same way that a brass player's lips and the tube of the instrument are sealed (or where the singers in this video have the tube shoved up against their mouths). If the system isn't sealed, there would certainly be no effect - but if it IS sealed properly, then... maybe. My guess would be that you might get similar results if you kept the volume low, but you could probably get the speaker to overpower the tube effect at some point. It would be an interesting experiment.

@Physics Girl, welcome to the strange world of woodwinds :) I'm a clarinet player so I had to learn about this stuff. What is happening is that with your mouth sealed over one end and blowing, the tube acts like a closed pipe. Because of the way the air vibrates in that kind of system, the 2nd order harmonics are inaccessible. Thus there is a gap in the frequencies it can produce. If you keep going up, it will jump into the 3rd order, skip the 4th, and then higher into the 5th order harmonics. This is how an instrument like a Clarinet operates. The interesting thing is if you uncap both sides of the pipe, like in a flute, then it can play all harmonic registers because the flute mouthpiece is open, and air can move in both directions. In a conical bore instrument like a saxophone the widening angle of the tube walls also allows for all harmonics to be accessible. But with close ended, straight bore pipes, we miss the 2nd and 4th harmonics. :) Thus the fingering for a "G" in the lower register plays a D in the 2nd (3rd harmonic) register. Where as on a saxophone a B is the same fingering in both registers. There is an excellent article about this here https://newt.phys.unsw.edu.au/jw/clarinetacoustics.html

When you sing close to a natural frequency, the tube changes the pitch to be at the natural frequency. As you get above the frequency, the pitch is still trying to maintain the natural frequency until it snaps away.

Let's say the natural frequency is A 440hz. As your voice tries to sing 441hz, the tube will resonate at 440hz still which is more energy than the 441hz. As your voice goes higher, there is a point where the frequency of the voice has more energy than the resonant frequency and as it prevails it creates a simultaneous drain in energy of the resonant frequency and the increase in the energy of the driven frequency which results in a jump. Resonance tries to force the voice to be at the resonant frequency until the gap gets too wide.

I studied vocal pedagogy in college (long ago), and the voice teacher did a similar experiment back then to show the resonating column of air.  Everything worked sensibly -- i.e. not like this video.  The difference was that the tube had a very large diameter -- 8 or 10 inches, as I recall.  (Obviously, one's mouth cannot come anywhere near covering this kind of opening.)  In that situation, introducing a sung pitch excited the air in the tube (or not), but the (large) size of the tube made it so the tube could not introduce any feedback to the vocal folds.  It did, however, have the uncanny effect of significantly amplifying the volume of the sung pitch when the sliding-up note got to the frequency of the tube.

I agree with the Professor (I think!) - the air pressure in the tube at its first resonant frequency is pressing back into the singer's own vocal resonant chambers, and this 'backward' force pushes against the vocal folds. That, plus the opposing pressure from the singer's support, force the vocal folds open. The voice therefore 'breaks'. A similar effect would, I suspect, occur using any resonator that can form a standing wave of a frequency matching that of one of the singer's attempted notes. (Like the tube, the breaking glass is also releasing some energy to the surroundings but, because it's not sealed around the singer's mouth, the pressure generated can dissipate, or set up a standing wave that gradually increases in amplitude 'til it's strong enhough to shatter the glass.)

I first experienced this phenomenon when I started playing the Tuba way back when I was in 6th grade (1999 to be exact).  One day, a few of us were playing around and "discovered" that if you sang into the Tuba it was amplified and sounded super interesting.  As we were "singing" into the Tuba's we found that there were certain frequencies that we just couldn't produce, and, like you showed in this video, sounded like our voices were cracking (and to be fair, my voice WAS cracking around that time).  Something you first learn when playing a brass instrument is that the instrument is basically a long pipe that is folded up on itself several times for convenience - Tuba's can be up to like 32 feet if you unraveled it completely - and that there are only a certain number of notes or frequencies that can be played, called its harmonic series (or sometimes referred to as an overtone series).  On a BBb Tuba the "open" harmonic series is Bb, F, Bb, D, F, Bb... etc.  Adding valves will add lengths of pipe that will augment the air flow and allow new harmonic series.  I always equated the "gaps" when singing into the Tuba as me reaching the end of one of these series and starting a new one.  This video makes a lot of sense and filled in those gaps :D

We musicians call a "dead" (less vibrant) note, at a particular string or position, or the whole instrument, a "Wolf" or woof. Did professor Wolfe start studying this phenomenon because he had the same name? lol <3
Pretty much every string instrument will have some wolfs, violins often around B flat above middle C, particularly played on the D string. Cellos can often have multiple and more prominent wolfs, which are often mediated by adding a weight to a string or two on the opposite side of the bridge from where the bow plays ..weights added randomly by experimentation to tune it out and lessen the effect of a tone crash or collapse.

There are a lot of musical instruments that utilize some of the acoustics you've demonstrated here. Brass instruments are the best example. Instead of singing into the tube, the player's lips act like the vocal cords. While there is some flexibility to what frequency the player's lips can vibrate, they only will resonate at the harmonics of the open pipe. If this pipe were conical or had a bell flare, the effect will be different. Something else that is interesting from a physics perspective is the effect of a stopped Horn (where the Horn player inserts their hand into the bell of the Horn to block the air leaving the instrument). In stopping the instrument, the frequency is lowered to a half-step above the next lower harmonic.


Towards the end of the video, you mention how singers match their vocal tract to match the frequency of the note sung. All woodwind and brass players will do this as well. Through the use of this sympathetic resonance, players can change the harmonics produced by their instrument (saxophone players are particularly adept at this).


Perhaps the best visual instrument for this is the Marimba (a percussion instrument - which is actually playing in the background of the video). Underneath the bars of the Marimba, which produce the sound, there are a series of resonators - identical to your PVC pipe. These resonators are tuned to the exact frequency of the fundamental and are used to acoustically amplify the sound which would otherwise be faint.

Have you heard of "Paradoxical Vocal Cord Dysfunction"? It can go by similar names, but the basic idea is that your vocal folds close when they should open, so you can't breathe. It's that "all choked up" feeling many people get during intense emotion, but some people (myself included) can get the same effect during an otherwise normal day.


It's related to this video because backpressure is one way to get breathing again. When you manage to get a breath in, purse your lips and hold your hand over your mouth to increase backpressure when you breathe out, and breathe out as forcefully as you can through the smaller opening. That backpressure somehow helps the vocal cords get back into sync again, and after several minutes I'm usually OK again. It used to take me a lot longer to recover before a speech therapist taught me the technique.


The point being, I agree with Prof. Wolfe that the likely culprit of your "can't hit the note" effect is indeed backpressure on the vocal cords. I have repeated evidence that my "can't breathe" episodes are significantly (measurably) changed by backpressure. The amount of backpressure is of course much greater in my case than the backpressure from the resonance in the tube, but then again the behavior change is also much greater (can't hit the note vs. can't breathe).


So there ya go -- another data point. If anyone truly cares, I could put on my research engineer hat and add some proper numbers on the data, but you get the idea: backpressure changing vocal fold behavior is indeed a thing.

You'll lower the resonant frequency of the tube by putting it to your mouth, making your mouth and throat part of the system. There are impedance mismatches with the opening to your mouth, the chamber of your mouth connecting to your throat, larynx, etc.

EDIT: Formant is a cool subject to think about with respect to the voice. For instance, when breathing helium gas versus normal air, it doesn't actually change the pitch of the vocal chords. It simply alters the speed of sound, and the resonant frequencies of the mouth and throat are affected by this. This causes peaks and troughs in the audio spectrum to shift higher with helium, giving the impression that pitch has changed when it hasn't. It's called a "Formant shift".
